channel.title: open-source on Yale Undergraduate Quantum Computing
channel.description: Recent content in open-source on Yale Undergraduate Quantum Computing

item.title: Recap 2020-21
item.description: tl;dr 30+ active members across disciplines Open Source Projects and Study Groups Quantum Coalition (Hack) & Partnerships & Outreach YuQC Invited Speaker Series Social Hours Resources Yale undergrad Quantum Computing was founded in October of 2020 and, in our first year, we’ve done quite a lot. Let’s take a look back at our productive year! Members As shown through data collected at our interest meeting, YuQC brought together students from across disciplines, school years, and experience levels.

item.title: YuQC Resources and Knowledge Database
item.description: Please take a look through the following database for resources that will help you learn more about quantum computation and quantum information science. Use the organizational features to sort items by type or by difficult level to suit your specific needs, or search directly for items! YuQC Resource Database To suggest other items to add to our database, please reach out to the Director of Resources: Shoumik Chowdhury. Additionally, PDFs of certain texts may be available upon request — reach out to learn more!

item.title: Quantum Programming API
item.description: About The goal of this project is to provide a quantum programming API that will help people who want to incorporate quantum speed-ups into their classical programs much easier. This project aims to both create the infrastructure to communicate with quantum systems and to create with that same infrastructure. We hope that our efforts in building this can lead to inspiration and further advances with the use of quantum computing in the broader computer science community.

item.title: Quantum Coalition Hackathon
item.description: Attend Please visit quantumcoalition.io to learn more about this exciting virtual hackathon co-hosted by Yale and Stanford, open to everyone, and sponsored by Quantum Computing industry innovators. Registration launches on February 14, 2021! Join the Organizing Committee If you are a YuQC member interested in joining the QC Hack Organizing Committee, please sign up here. Sponsors Coming soon…

item.title: Project Ideas
item.description: Projects: efforts ranging open-source packages to hackathon events to resource development and more! SUBMIT YOUR PROJECT IDEAS: Have an idea for a project? Click here to propose a project! NOTE: Each project requires a corresponding project proposal that can be filled out and submitted later. Click here for the template for the write-up. Join a project team: Want to see what we’re working on? Click here to check out our project spreadsheet.

item.title: Open-source Resources
item.description: Here are some resources to help you along with your open source quantum endeavours. QC Open Source Projects Quantum Open Source Foundation Open Source Projects Mentorship Learning Prizes and Funding Projects Unitary Fund Non-profit Microgrants Research projects

item.title: Qiskit
item.description: Qiskit is IBM’s open source quantum computing SDK. There is a vibrant community of open source developers and quantum advocates. Getting Started Join the Qiskit slack! Here are some curated tutorials to get yourself started with Qiskit and the IBM Quantum Experience: Code your first quantum circuit CH 1-3 of Qiskit Textbook Beginner Tutorials Events Stay up to date with Qiskit events. Past events: Hackathons IBM Qiskit Global Summer School Quantum Advocates Apply to become one of ~200 Quantum Advocate across ~30 countries at IBM.

item.title: qtcodes
item.description: Status qtcodes is published on PyPI with tooling to encode, decode and benchmark XXXX/ZZZZ surface code, XZZX surface code, and repetition code! About We are building Encoder and Minimum Weight Perfect Matching Graph Decoder tools for serveral Topological Codes we wish to implement in Qiskit Ignis. Here is the Github repo: https://github.com/yaleqc/qtcodes Here is a link to our project proposal. Team The first iteration of this project was created by members Shantanu Jha ‘21, Henry Liu ‘21, Will Sun ‘22, Shraddha Singh (Grad), and Andy Ding (Grad).
